stream_context.summary: Kaze codes and tests a new “seesaw Goomba” set-piece for the Bowser factory level of Return to Yoshi’s Island while also showing the huge competition level “Only Up 64.”  He optimises N64 performance (back-face culling, triangle pruning), discusses new collision tech, enemy designs, and the project’s music gap.
level: Course 2 – Bowser Fleet Factory / Oily Boily Bay

development_findings.summary: ‘Only Up 64’ level is ~60 % complete, projected to take players ~25 minutes to climb, and Kaze aims to keep it N64-compatible despite its unprecedented size.
Factory level currently renders ~13 000 triangles; enabling back-face culling on metal/scaffold textures lifted worst-case framerate from 19 FPS to ~25 FPS on real hardware.
development_findings.quote: Backface culling is insane… this was 19, now it's 25.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to split the red-coin section into a separate area or pipe if further optimisation is needed.
New collision engine tweaks make ceiling contacts ‘a lot more stable,’ and several new collision codes have been added.
development_findings.quote: You guys probably can't really tell the difference but it's very noticeable when you're walking into ceilings… it's a lot more stable now.

development_findings.summary: Seesaw set-piece: a Goomba stands on the front of a plank; breaking a box tilts the plank, squashing or upsetting the Goomba.  Kaze prototyped physics, bounce, sound and safety logic during stream.
development_findings.quote: I want the player to be able to stop it from falling while Mario is still on there.

development_findings.summary: Division-by-zero crash on N64 traced to the compiler pipelining the DIV into a branch delay slot; fixed by rearranging instructions.
development_findings.quote: The compiler decided to pipeline the division into the delay slot… so no matter what happens I always divide by 0.

development_findings.summary: New Tox Box models with higher-res textures and more expressive faces are finished.
Footstep system still has room for ~5 new surface sound types; metal footstep sound may be replaced.
development_findings.quote: We actually still have space for I think five sound-step games.

development_findings.summary: Womp ‘construction worker’ enemy concept: carries a steel beam, helmet belted to its back (the vulnerable spot).  Mission will have Mario kick them over.
development_findings.quote: It would be funny if their helmet was on their back… then you just kick them over.

development_findings.summary: Game uses the 8 MB Expansion Pak; could technically fit 4 MB by loading areas and code separately, but Kaze deems effort not worth it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is juggling the hack, an ‘Only Up’ contest level, and a tech-conference presentation, leaving him ‘so busy actually I will never have my freedom.’
context_findings.quote: Man I'm so busy actually I will never have my freedom.

context_findings.summary: Heat wave affects his stream (“literally gonna die from this heat”) and mood.
Removed sponsorship from Brilliant; YouTube revenue alone is ‘barely profitable,’ limiting how much he can pay collaborators.
context_findings.quote: My YouTube channel is barely profitable, especially now that Brilliant doesn't sponsor me anymore.

context_findings.summary: Works a salaried programming job (remote Danish company) but avoids sharing salary out of respect for employer.
Streams on ‘Kaze Clips’ to avoid hurting main-channel algorithm; values creative freedom over reach.
context_findings.quote: I can just upload whatever the fuck I want and I don't really care if that fucks my algorithm.

context_findings.summary: Frustration with YouTube latency; tried low-latency toggle but viewers still ~30 s behind.

biobak.summary: Actively suggests visual tweaks (textures, culling), jokes with Kaze, and will supply a Bowser factory trailer for F3.

badub.summary: Scheduled to compose music but ‘been missing in attendance,’ leaving current OST plans uncertain.
badub.quote: I thought Badub was gonna make a song but Badub's been missing… not sure what to expect there.

zeina.summary: Created animations for the new enemy (‘cement pit guy’) off-stream.
zeina.quote: Zeina made the animations for this guy already.

key_stories.title: Back-face Culling Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Real-hardware tests of the enormous factory level tanked to 19 FPS.  By selectively enabling back-face culling on scaffold and metal materials, Kaze clawed back 6–7 FPS without visible quality loss on console.
key_stories.challenge: Level dropped below playable framerate on N64.
key_stories.process: Measured triangle counts, identified unseen faces, toggled material flags, re-tested.
key_stories.outcome: Worst-case view now ~25 FPS; decision to ship with culling on console only.
key_stories.key_quote: Backface culling is insane… that was 19, now it's 25.

key_stories.title: Compiler Betrayal
key_stories.summary: A mysterious N64 crash revealed the compiler had reordered instructions so a division by zero always executed.  Kaze caught it by comparing emu vs console behaviour.
key_stories.challenge: Floating-point exception on real hardware while emu worked.
key_stories.process: Inspected disassembly, spotted DIV in branch delay slot, rearranged instructions in ClipMario.
key_stories.outcome: Crash resolved in both Return to Yoshi’s Island and Only Up repositories.
key_stories.key_quote: The compiler decided that no matter what happens I always divide by 0.

key_stories.title: Designing the Seesaw Goomba
key_stories.summary: Kaze prototypes a comic ‘worker sabotage’ where Mario breaks a box, tipping a plank to flatten a Goomba.
key_stories.challenge: Make the animation readable, predictable, and performant on N64.
key_stories.process: Iterated on angular velocity, bounce, positional offsets, sound cues, and Goomba detachment; live-tested on hardware.
key_stories.outcome: Visual gag works; next step is fine-tuning Goomba behaviour and player teaching.
key_stories.key_quote: I want the player to be able to stop it from falling while Mario is still on there.

open_questions.context: Kaze expected Badub to provide songs but composer hasn’t appeared for some time.
questions: What is the planned musical style for the factory world and overall hack?
Has Badub officially stepped back or is this temporary?
Contingency plans if new compositions don’t arrive?

open_questions.context: Player must figure out how to mess with five different workers (Goomba, cement guy, oil barrels, Womp, overseer) but no tutorial exists yet.
questions: How will level design communicate each sabotage method organically?
Any UI or dialogue cues planned?
Has play-testing revealed confusion points?
Which team member leads puzzle readability?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions ‘new collision codes’ and ceiling stability improvements.
questions: What specific problems did vanilla SM64 collision have?
What algorithms or data structures replaced them?
Any breakthrough moments or unexpected side-effects?
Could visuals show old vs new behaviour?

open_questions.context: Level pushes 13 k triangles; Kaze weighs aesthetics against 30 FPS target.
questions: Is there a formal polygon or draw-call budget per area?
How does the team decide when to split an area?
Any tools to automate culling or LOD?
Lessons learned from previous hacks?

open_questions.context: Concept shown but no animation or behaviour yet.
questions: What emotions or humour are you targeting with this enemy?
How will steel-beam physics be handled?
Will the helmet vulnerability be visually clear?
Any inspirations from real construction imagery?

open_questions.context: Brilliant sponsorship ended; YouTube revenue ‘barely profitable.’
questions: How are development costs currently covered?
Does Kaze plan Patreon, merch, or publisher support?
How does financial pressure influence scope and timelines?
How are collaborators compensated or credited?
